description: $A$  The area of a bean zone; the number of pixels within its boundaries.
$P$  The bean circumference, i.e., the length of its border.
$L$  The length of the longest straight line that can be drawn within the circumference of a bean.
$l$ The longest closed line segment of a bean that is (a) perpendicular to the major axis, and (b) bounded by the bean circumference.

$K$ Ratio $\frac{L}{l}$, i.e., (major axis length)/(minor axis length).
Formula: $\frac{L}{l}$

$Ec$ The eccentricity $e$ of an ellipse is a measure of degree of circularity; $0 \le e < 1$.
$\sqrt{1 - \frac{l^2}{L^2}}$
$C$  _The number of pixels in the smallest convex polygon that can contain the area of a bean seed._

$Ed$  _The diameter of a circle having the same area as a bean seed area._  Cf.  The [IUPAC definition](https://doi.org/10.1351/goldbook.E02191) of an equivalent diameter $\rightarrow$ *...diameter of a spherical particle which will give identical geometric, optical, electrical or aerodynamic behaviour to that of the particle (non-spherical) being examined...*
$Ex$  _The ratio of the pixels in the bounding box to the bean area._
$S$  _Also known as convexity. The ratio of the pixels in the convex shell to those found in beans._
Class $\rightarrow$ Seker, Barbunya, Bombay, Cali, Dermosan, Horoz and Sira
